values:
There are certain ways my life should be.
I promised a friend I would write all these down, and send it to someone or post it somewhere, and I'm frankly not sure why, but I told him I would.

I'm supposed to write emails to all my friends all over the country once a week or once a month, depending.

I'm supposed to living alone, but in a relationship that's clearly leading to marriage and home ownership and kitchen remodeling, etc.

I'm supposed to have a job with loads of responsibility, and make enough money to take one or two vacations a year.

I'm supposed to be well-read and interesting.

I'm supposed to  be outgoing and at ease with strangers.

I'm supposed have cute shoes that fit me.  

I'm supposed to have a dishwasher and a car that has four doors painted the same color.

I'm supposed to go to gallery openings regularly and I'm supposed to drink wine, not hard lemonade.

I am supposed to like wine.

I am supposed to work out three to five times a week, balancing aerobic training with yoga, and weights here and there for good measure.

I am supposed to cook most of my meals from scratch, from local and organic ingredients whenever possible.

I am supposed to bicycle to work.

I am supposed to use my TV to watch only the daily show and possibly one or two other guilty pleasures.

I am supposed to be up on current books, movies, music, popular culture, and politics.  

I am supposed to have a trim yet feminine waistline, a strong back, and be able to carry my end of any piece of furniture I own when I'm moving out of my appartment.

I am supposed to have a washer and dryer, and fold my clothes immediately upon taking them out of the dryer.

I am supposed to have spectacular health insurance.

I am supposed to be giving, generous, and aware of others, without exception.

I'm supposed to take time for me where I'm not just tuning out and engaging in passive entertainmenet.

I'm not supposed to trail off in hte middle of my sentences, I'm supposed to speak clearly and concisely in a way that makes a difference for my listner, or else I'm supposed to keep my mouth shut. 

I'm supposed to be five feet, five inches tall.

I'm supposed to have my teaching certificate, but not be a teacher, instead doing something unusual and fascinating in the education field.

I'm supposed to have a retirement fund and save ten percent of my earnings every month.

I'm supposed to shave my legs.

I'm supposed to love either cats or dogs, and have one that I take excellent care of, even chuckling good-naturedly when their hair is all over my black dress slacks.

I'm supposed to have an army of dress slacks.

I'm supposed to look great in a little black dress, have casual wear that includes blazer-cut jackets, an antique engagement ring, and pointy-toed shoes that make my body look long and lean.

Anything else?

Oh, and I should shop at IKEA, use a power-drill, chop my vegetables impeccable, be an activist, donate money to important causes, march in the streets, call my senators, and meditate daily.


there's more, I'm sure, but now it's long after I was supposed to go to bed.
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/174676.html

I'm walking back from the catholic school to the daycare center with a big group of elementary school kids, just like I do every day.  

A seven year old drama queen who always gets her way (totally unlike me at that age) is telling me that the the way I look at her when telling her to stop doing something she shouldn't is mean.

Girl: I think you should say it like we say it in church, we look into the other person's eyes and say "peace be with you"
Me: Okay.  So you think that tone of voice would be better?  What do I look like now?
Girl (stage whispers): You look at me like you don't believe in Jesus.

Love,
S
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/174396.html

Best email adress ever: twatkins.
Given that this last person's name is watkins and they chose an email like this? and, given the number following twatkins, so did a couple hundred other people?

Brilliant.

Also, according to a five year old girl, the secret of world peace:
"Be kind, safe, and respecful, and don't cry to make other people feel bad."

Love,
Squashy.

"there is no creative impulse in the absence of discontent"

Deepak Chopra was interviewed on the Colbert Report, suggesting that, yes, heaven as an afterlife was an okay idea and everything, but it would be consignment to eternal senility.

~S
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/173980.html

Hello All!

I am at my grandmother's house in oregon and thought I'd give an update in case anyone still actually checks this thing.

(Megan, I'm going to call you soon, like maybe tomorrow, if I don't lose your number before then, to firm up whether I can stay with you in chicago or not.)

Let's see.
Right. so I'm at my grandmother's house on the coast of oregon, and dad's here too, and we're helping her pack up her house to move, as it sold unexpectedly quickly and . . . here we are!  Right.  

So we spent an alarming portion of the day packing up my grandmother's  glass menagerie, composed mainly of unicorns but faries and ceramic teddy bears as well.

there's a plum tree in her yard that produces amazingly good plums, and blackberry bushes with some of the only wild blackberries I've ever found sweet enough.  (in the back yard, though. the ones in the front are terrible.)

I'm trying desperately to stay on eastern time, but it's not going well so far--it's past my bedtime back east, but it's only nine here!  Yuck.

Also, I'm dating a really great guy.  I thought I would mention that.  Because I'm telling everyone all the fucking time 'cause it's so cool and I'm, like, fifteen years old.  And Sleep-deprived.

Love,
Squashy
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/173754.html

Namely, am I ready to live alone?

I love, love, *love* living with my roommate.  He's moving away.  There are a lot of options before me, none of them all *that* attractive.  Well, one is pretty attractive, namely having a friend move in, but that's looking unlikely.  What can I do instead?

And what would it be like if I lived alone?

I would spend even more time on the phone, for one thing. And I'd be online more.  I'd probably get repetitive strain injury.  
And I'd have plenty of room in the refrigerator for all my things. 
And umm . . . 
I'd have to be okay with being alone, which is a pretty new concept for me. 

Okay, I need to go clean the kitchen now.

Love,
Squashy
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/173529.html

Here is my thought for today:

There's this dad of a girl at work who told me that (since he picked her up crying because she lost a game) he doesn't want her participating in said game anymore.  

I said fine.

I thought "Dude, if your ten-year-old can't handle someone thinking shes's less than the perfect princess you think she is, you might as well check her into an eating disorder clinic right now."

Because she *is* a great kid, but how does sheltering her from defeats and normal minor unhappiness help her grow as a person?

And that is my opinion. 

Love, 
Squashy

Okay, so I'm on OKCupid sorting personals by how compatible a guy is with me, and I decided to sort by "enemy percentage" instead of highest match.

The ickyiest guy within 20 miles of me is a 57% enemy, looks like a typical frat boy,and introduces himself with this winning line:

_I'm a sarcastic person who enjoys drinking and making out with strangers at clubs. I am single and love it so I don't want any ugly people to message me. Oh, and no fatties, either. I really...really....REALLY don't like gay people._

Are my non-single friends grateful to be off the market right now? 
I hope so.

Love,
Squashy
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/171829.html

Here is a dialogue between me and my roommate at a play last night, during intermission.

A bug flies by.

Him: Oh my god! I thought that was a may fly!
Me: Or just a really well-endowed horsefly.
Him: Tell me you didn't just make that up yourself.
Me: I did.
Him: Well . . . They don't call them horseflies for nothin.

Love,
Squashy

To all my loves: 

Someone sent me a gift subscription to my favorite magazine, which is (make fun of me if you must) Oprah magazine.

 . . . Was it you?
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/171204.html

Here's me trying to get a kid to sleep at naptime. I count this conversation as one of my major victories for the week.

Squashy: I need you to lay down on your cot.
Toddler: No.

Squashy: You need to lay your body down.
Todder: No.

Squashy: Put your head on your pillow.
Toddler: No.

Squashy: Lay down.
Todder: No.

Squashy: Abracadabra.
Toddler: No.

Squashy: Alacazam.
Toddler: No.

Squashy: Hepzebahflurge.
Toddler: No.

Squashy: Red. 
Toddler: (Giggles.) No!

Squashy: Blue.
Toddler: (delighted) Okay, you say all the colors, and I say no!!

Squashy: Only if you lay down.
Toddler: Okay!

So now we have a new game to play that he's very, very happy with, and I get to increase his color vocabulary. Yay!

He never did go to sleep that afternoon, but later he told me a great story about how Simba from the lion king came to his classroom, ate snack, and played with the toys.

I love my job!  

Love,
Squashy
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/170810.html

Here is a conversation I had with a six year old boy that I will not be putting in the newsletter that I send out to parents:

Boy: My kitten walks around with her butt in the air all the time.
Me: She does?
Boy: And I know why.
Me: Why's that?
Boy: Because she's in love with the neighbor cat, Beavis.
Me: Yeah, cats do that sometimes
Boy: He's not nice.  He peed on our picnic blanket.
Me: Hmm, he doesn't sound like a very good boyfriend.

Also, this is what I got today when I went to a four-year-old with the prompt "can you tell me a scary story?"

"Once upon a time there was a ghost that had four stomachs, and he was hungry, so he wanted something to eat.  He decided to eat a witch! but then he was tired, so he took a nap.  That's th eend.

I was all "weird, my friends havent' been updating! at all!"
But it turns out that my friends page (the "actual friends" version) hasn't been updating, and y'all have been updating, and it's absolute bullshit. I say.

So I'm over 30 entries out of date in reading up on what y'all are up to, collectively.

Maybe someone wrote about my birthday party.

That would be nice.

Damn, I'm about to be real late for work.

Love,
Squashy

Hello.

I'm going to sleep now.
I haven't really written to or called anyone because... well, because I haven't. 

I love you all. 

The guy I went on a decent date with became the really cool guy I'm seeing exclusively.
I like him a lot.  

The punchline is that his personality is a *lot* like my dad's, (and the polar opposite of mine) but I'm working very hard to not let that freak me out at this point.  

Having given you that nugget of personal information, here's a nifty article on the science of happiness and its chilly reception in the UK:
http://www.timesonline.co.uk/printFriendly/0,,1-100-1793873-531,00.html
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/169235.html

Hello My Loves!!!

I have been meaning very hard to write to Lux, Photodiva, Alicat, Bananda, and Ruthy (in addition to intending other forms of communication with others of you) so I thought I would, as they say, just do it now.

(actually, that's not what they say. but it's close.)

Life is totally, totally awesome right now.
I did a fan-fucking-tastic seminar in July that, as you are more or less aware, totally rocked my world, and cleared out some room in my life to do less bitching and more taking on of big things.

These are the projects going on in my life right now:

1.) We're having a housewarming party! yay!  Can my richmond friends come? You could carpool to save money on gas, and then maybe you could like, talk and get to know one another better! Which you totally should, as you are excellent people and, if given the time and place, I think would like each other very much. I'll give you the date in personal correspondence.

2.)The after-school program I'm running is AMAZING.  We're getting donations left and right, the five-year-olds are learning chess, the boys are learning to knit and sew, leaves are being pressed and pictures drawn as we merrily wend our way into the academic year.  The kids had two big projects, hurricane relief and a sale of their arts/crafts for the holidays, and they've decided to combine the two--they'll be selling scarves, doll clothes, bookmarks, and god knows what else they've made, then donating the proceeds to whatever charity we choose, probably the red cross.  The showstopper should be the collection of burgundy chenille scarves that we're going to make, thanks to an extraordinarily generous donation of the biggest ... thing... (it's not a skein) of yarn I've ever seen.  As one girl was leaving the room, she announced that she'd be very surprised if we make less than $100 on this event, and I have to say, I'm starting to agree with her.

3.) I am learning to be a competent driver, very slowly, as it is not all that easy to acquire the use of both a person's car and a person's time to make this happen.  (The roommate's truck is a quirky old toyota with a stick shift and no power steering, which makes it extremely hard to drive, plus I suspect he'll never let me behind the wheel again, since I drove it for two miles with the parking brake on, *not* that this is something that ever happened before or will ever happen again or anything.)  I've decided that if the point is learning city driving, I need to be in an automatic.  Period. Learning stick is for when someone has the time and patience to teach me.

4.) I might be taking out a bank loan and buying a car in the next two weeks.  Then again, I might not.  I also might rent a car to go home for thanksgiving.  No matter how I get there, though, I'm going home for thanksgiving and I'm driving, even if that means doing that hour from the bus stop to home in my mom's car.

5.) I went out on a couple dates with a guy I like. I'm reserving judgement for as long as possible.  

6.)  I'm starting a literary magazine at the preschool.  I expect it will mostly be descriptions of pictures they've drawn (along with pictures) but stories and quotations as well, and .  It was inspired by a drawing done by a three year old of a little pink girl standing on a little green house, and the wonderful poetry she spoke as she told me about her picture.  

"It's about a pepperoni and a peach and copper.  And the author is my name is Ariel teacher disneyland girl.  And she loves the whole world, even the sky.  And that's me!"

Loving even the sky, 
Squashy
http://squashyduck.livejournal.com/168982.html

I just got an icebreaker on an online personals site--this means a guy sent me a free content-less generic message expressing his interest in me.

This has to be the best "more about who I'm looking for" that I've ever seen:

"I'm looking for my kind.She has to posses my qualities.Must be very pretty and charming.She must not be stingy,greedy and sellfish.Must be very intelligent.Above all,she must have the fear of God in her heart."

(Maybe I should change my heading to "No, really! I'm an atheist!"  Right now it says "This insightful and compelling headline magically deflects conservatives!" which I had hoped would serve the same purpose.)

Love,
Squashy

Pure Nerd
78 % Nerd, 26% Geek, 43% Dork
For The Record:

A Nerd is someone who is passionate about learning/being smart/academia.
A Geek is someone who is passionate about some particular area or subject, often an obscure or difficult one.
A Dork is someone who has difficulty with common social expectations/interactions.
You scored better than half in Nerd, earning you the title of: Pure Nerd.

The times, they are a-changing. It used to be that being exceptionally smart led to being unpopular, which would ultimately lead to picking up all of the traits and tendences associated with the "dork." No-longer. Being smart isn't as socially crippling as it once was, and even more so as you get older: eventually being a Pure Nerd will likely be replaced with the following label: Purely Successful.

Congratulations!


Also, you might want to check out some of my other tests if you're interested in any of the following:

Buffy the Vampire Slayer

Professional Wrestling

Love & Sexuality

America/Politics

Thanks Again! -- THE NERD? GEEK? OR DORK? TEST

Okay.  I should probably turn the computer off.

So, as an empowerment type thing, I've decided to tackle the impossible and learn how to drive.  And buy a car.  And drive said car home for thanksgiving.

So what I really need to do right now is get a budget in place and find out where and when to take my permit test.

Know what I'm doing instead?

Dicking around with online personals.

Le sigh.

Even sleeping would be better.

Also, I think my phone is malfunctioning and no longer ringing.  

Okay. So. to do a budget I need to umm... write down all my monthly expenses in the same place.  
like the bills and stuff.
Including student loans. 

Off I go! 
Love,
Squashy

I am absolutely dead serious that this is a bitchin' place to work, and I would *love* to talk to your second cousin once removed or whatever about it.

Love,

In a rare bit of LJ-drama, I suspect that Davin is passive-agressively trying to tell me he reads my LJ without my permission.

That being said (and having been posted solely for my own amusement) I'm really excited and nervous and all sorts of things about my new job on monday.

Basically, I work at the best preschool in the city. and we have a summer program for schoolage kids, which is, somehow, *not* one of the best in the city. To put it delicately.  It's just kind of ... like daycare or babysitting, really. no cool activities, no enrichment. 
I won't say anything else beyond that, but ... yeah. not cool.

So my goal is, in the three weeks remaining in the program, to completely turn it around and make it as good as the preschool.

Like, woah.

So, right. I have a lot of stuff to do, starting with dealing with the angry parents who are unhappy with how the program is going.
And umm . . . 

But I feel ready to do that! yes!

So I'm going to work on my plans now.

Love,
Squashy

I'm still not caught up on my friends page reading, but I love you all.

So this weekend I did a seminar.  After doing said seminar, I developed the following 
Being an extraordinary teacher every single day, empowering students, ending bullying in my classroom, going to my boss and asking her to create a special position just for me since I'm too awesome for part time, living alone and loving it,  being comfortable in my identity as an adult, and bringing my family together for a vacation even though we're all broke.
Two weeks ago I thought those things were either maybe possible someday, or they hadn't even occurred to me.
Since sunday every single one of those things is three quarters accomplished.

For instance:
When there was bullying before, I used feel it was (unsatisfactorially) resolved when both sides were okay. Now it's only resolved when both sides are empowered.

Honestly, since bullying is the most important issue in any classroom, (to me anyway, since it scarred me for life) that was worth $410 all by myself.

I've been at my best every single moment this week. 

My in short possibility for my life is the possibility of being vibrant and empowering. And you know what? I am.

Love,
Squashy

P.S. if you live in the US or Canada, it's pure stupidity that's kept me from calling you: I have unlimited long distance.  Send me your number if you'd fancy a chat!

Working with children?
It keeps you humble.

This is a conversation I had with four-year-old twins and their mother as I was leaving work today.  We started by talking about the Washington DC zoo.

Brother: "I don't even think you know how to get there!"

Me: "that's right, I might have to ride in your car!"

The mom: "What do you think guys, should we strap her to the roof and take her along?"

kids: "Noooooooo"

Me: "Why Not?"

Sister: "it would not be safe!"

Brother: "If we had to stop suddenly your glasses might fall off!"

Truer words never spoken.

Love,
Squashy

Hooray! I got an email from lux! And photodiva comments on my entries!

News: I got a promotion at work to being the lead teacher in the school-age program. My boss told me that she's been really impressed with my performance and what I've been learning.  It's only a half-time position, so I'll still be subbing a lot to get near full-time hours enough to keep my health insurance, but I get to decorate a classroom and plan lessons and stuff! yay!

And the hours: two to six pm, weekdays, full time school holidays and in the summer. Sweet!
And that leaves me enough time to take college classes in early childhood!


The negative: this position is contingent on my learning how to drive a fifteen passenger van.

*So*

Since I don't know how to drive, period,  I'll have to take professional classes, which will be very expensive, but with any luck I'll be a very safe driver by the end of it.

Heh. Luck.

Love,
Squashy

Squee! Squee and double squee! and triple squee!  I am so happy!

At the preschool where I work, each classroom has three teachers who work in a team.  
I'm a substitute teacher.  
A favorite teacher of mine, in whose classroom I recently did a two week stint, was going on maternity leave, and I really wanted to sub for her, but the brand new assistant director put someone else instead--perfectly reasonable, she just didn't know.
*But* it turns out that that someone else can't do it, so I get seven glorious weeks in one of my favorite classrooms with some completely awesome kids! I actually get to do some planning! and have responsibilities! but not too many!

Highlights of today:

One of the coteachers told me she had begged the director to put me in the classroom 'cause she wanted to do it.

Parent of one of the coolest kids ever told me that she's glad I'm doing it 'cause she thinks I'm a great teacher. 

Other parents of also cool kids expressed happiness in this as well.

Got large paycheck.

Realized there are only ten more days till harry potter!

Acquired allergy medicine leading to allergy shot leading possibly to normal eating habits again instead of avoiding corn wheat, beef, dairy, tomatoes, potatoes, and soy in diet.

Got paid a little overtime.

Got child with behavior problems to lay on his cot and sleep at naptime.

~*~

So one of the things about subbing is that you don't really have hte same schedule day to day, you don't know if there'll be room in the fridge for your lunch, funny kindergartener stuff like that.
*but* I will now be coming in daily at the same perfectly reasonable hour for seven glorious weeks.

What a sweet fuckin' chance to prove myself and what I've learned!!

Love,
Squashy

Today at work I was comforting a little girl who was crying for her dad on the playground. (she's three).  Her older brother, who is five, happened to be on hand.  I asked him if there's anything she likes to do with their dad, since happy memories of daddy might distract her.

His response?
"Sometimes she joins him in conversation."

(This, you see, is what American children with British mothers are like.) 

With love,
Squashy

Hey Sweeties!

I haven't been updating.

What have I been doing?
Spending not much time on the computer, for one. 
(also I ripped a thumbnail and now typing hurts, but that's just today.)

I've been on the computer surprisingly little lately.

What have I been doing?

Weeeeelll, I went to photodiva's wedding in New Hampshire. 
And I've been subbing full time at the preschool, and totally loving it.

Today at work a girl asked me what the dedication page of a book said. I read it to her, and it finished with "brining the joy of reading to children everywhere."  She told me I "sound like PBS kids."
Which is totally the best compliment I"ve ever gotten from a kid. I sound like a PBS announcer!

I've got a subbing job in the *same room* for the next two weeks. Hoooraaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay!

Big shoutout to photodiva for posting on the last meme. yaaaaaaaaay! thank you!

I bought a VCR this weekend!  Yaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay! I bought it at a yard sale for $2.
It goes nicely with my yard sale TV.

I was walking home through my quiet little tree-and-garden residential neighborhood today when I stopped to smell some roses. Out of nowhere (I had my headphones on) this older woman comes up to me and asks if I'd like some to take home. I was dumbfounded, so she said "You don't have to take them!"  and I recovered sufficiently to say that I would enjoy them. She told me to stay right there and she came back with garden shears and cut me four big brances of pink rambling roses, which I took home and are now sitting in a red glass vase on my kitchen table.

I decided that since I was literally stopping to smell the roses when this happened, this is the universe's way of telling me that it's really okay to just be mellow and kinda lazy like I am . . . just chill and enjoying the moment.

Speaking of enjoyable moments, I had a kid say today that there were no dinosaurs "in the eighties. When the titanic sank."

Love,
Squashy
